title: Remote ischaemic preconditioning versus no remote ischaemic preconditioning for vascular and endovascular surgical procedures
authors: Liang, F; Liu, S; Liu, G; Liu, H; Wang, Q; Song, B; Yao, L

response.output:
Remote ischaemic preconditioning (RIPC), a technique that briefly restricts blood flow to a limb to protect distant organs, has been studied to see if it helps people undergoing major vascular surgery. The evidence suggests that RIPC does not make a clear difference in reducing perioperative mortality, myocardial infarction, renal impairment, stroke, hospital stay, or operating time in people undergoing elective major vascular and endovascular surgery.

The review included 14 randomized controlled trials that compared RIPC with no RIPC in adults undergoing elective major vascular and endovascular surgery. The studies found no clear difference in perioperative mortality, myocardial infarction, renal impairment, stroke, hospital stay, and operating time, and may lead to little or no difference in limb loss.

The certainty of evidence for the main outcomes was moderate due to imprecision of results, moderate heterogeneity, or possible publication bias. The studies were at low to unclear risk of bias for most risk of bias domains.

Overall, compared with no RIPC, RIPC probably leads to little or no difference in perioperative mortality, myocardial infarction, renal impairment, stroke, hospital stay, and operating time, and may lead to little or no difference in limb loss in people undergoing elective major vascular and endovascular surgery. Adequately powered and designed randomised studies are needed, focusing in particular on the clinical endpoints and patient-centred outcomes.

The evidence is current as of the latest available data up to October 2025.
